awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alex Blumenthal is "Random and infinite-dimensional dynamical systems." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Maryland, and the sponsoring scientist is Dmitry Dolgopyat.

por.por_cntn:
Many systems in nature, from large systems such as the weather, to small systems such as the fluid motion in a cup of water, are fundamentally chaotic or unpredictable. One way this manifests is the Butterfly Effect, i.e., sensitivity with respect to initial conditions: even very small changes to the initial state of the system can amplify to large differences at later times. Put differently, for chaotic systems, although the present determines the future, the approximate present does not determine the approximate future.

Although chaos or unpredictability is strongly suspected to be quite common, it is notoriously challenging to verify the presence of permanent, long-time chaos in a mathematically rigorous way, even in the face of strong numerical evidence suggesting so. The reason is that opposing dynamical regimes, e.g., chaotic versus 'ordered' or non-chaotic, can be intertwined in a convoluted way. This is already known to be the case for extremely simple and well-studied families of systems, for instance the logistic family of maps on the one-dimensional unit interval.

On the other hand, chaotic regimes in the real world are much more robust than this. A possible reason why is that most real-world systems are subjected to some noisy input from the outside world. A primary goal of this research grant was to explore how noisy inputs can 'unleash' chaotic behavior in a given system, enhancing the scope of systems for which chaotic properties can be checked in a mathematically rigorous way. One highlight of the work conducted in this grant was the proof of chaotic properties for the Lagrangian flow in various models in fluid mechanics. This flow describes the motion of a passive tracer particle (for instance, a piece of dust or a small plastic bead) as it is moved around by the fluid motion. Joint with Jacob Bedrossian (U Maryland) and Samuel Punshon-Smith (Brown), we showed that this motion is chaotic in that it is sensitive with respect to initial conditions when the fluid is subjected to some non degenerate noisy driving. Work on this simplified model explains, mathematically, the complicated striations and folds you see as you pour milk into your coffee and stir it in.

The work conducted during the tenure of this grant resulted in the submission of eight papers to leading mathematics journals, four of which have been accepted for publication. Additionally, this work was disseminated at thirty conference talks, seminars and colloquia. Additional broader impacts included: (1) informal mentoring of three graduate students at U Maryland and elsewhere, and (2) co-organizing the Spring 2019 Semiannual Dynamical Systems and Related Topics workshop at U Maryland, for which we achieved gender parity among our invited speakers.
